item.title: Scientific programming languages
item.description:
Alexander Nozik, physicist and programmer, head of the Nuclear Physics Methods Laboratory at JetBrains Research, deputy head of the Laboratory of Methods of Nuclear Physics Experiments and master’s program at MIPT - about how to transfer scientific code to a modern stack and why it is difficult to introduce new tools into science. This article is based on a December 2021 episode of Skillbox’s People and Code podcast.

‚Äî Alexander, tell us what you do and what problems you solve?

‚Äî My main place of work is the Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology (MIPT), also known as Phystech. In addition, I work at the Institute of Nuclear Research of the Russian Academy of Sciences and JetBrains Research - this is a community of laboratories associated with JetBrains. The company supports laboratories and thus gathers the scientific community around itself.

I am engaged in neutrino physics, this is the main direction of my scientific activity. But in recent years I have been developing more software and libraries for scientific research.

‚Äî How does science differ from commercial development in terms of tasks? How does this affect the choice of tools and programming languages?

‚Äî Science has always been and remains ‚Äúfaster, higher, stronger‚Äù than other spheres. Scientists often solve the same problems as in commercial development, but on a much larger scale. Let’s remember the Internet protocol HTTP: it was originally created so that scientific centers could exchange large amounts of data. In one of the corridors of CERN there is even a sign: ‚ÄúThe Internet was invented in this room.‚Äù

In particle acceleration experiments at the Large Hadron Collider, if memory serves, 25 GB of data are generated per minute. For commercial projects this is simply incomprehensible. We work with volumes of data that are not available anywhere else.

Data analysis and so-called Data Science have already become part of the industry. ‚ÄúSo-called‚Äù because there is still no clear definition of what kind of science this is. Nevertheless, all the methodology and new tools are developed by scientists, because only they can operate with complex mathematical models.

An important feature of science is that there are very few professional programmers in it. Therefore, the tools that scientists use must not only be the most flexible and fastest, but also simple. Otherwise, non-programmer scientists will create such a thing that no one will be able to figure it out later. Actually, something similar has already happened in physics, and now the scientific community is solving this problem.

The fact is that physicists write computational code in C++, and then wrap it in Python code. And it seems to me that this approach has outlived its usefulness: in Python it is very difficult to maintain a large code base, and here the size of projects is growing precisely on the side of the users of the code - scientists. Therefore, such systems are slowly falling apart and over the past five years, engineers and scientists have been looking for more flexible and simpler alternatives.

‚Äî Do other sciences use the same combination of languages?

‚Äî Yes, it‚Äôs about the same everywhere, but with a slight difference. For example, bioinformatics as a separate field has emerged relatively recently. Unlike physicists who had to ‚Äúswitch‚Äù to Python, they immediately began working in modern languages. But most sciences still use C, Fortran and C++ libraries, and write a Python add-on on top of them. And now there are the same problems with flexibility.

In addition to Python, in various fields of science they write or have tried to write in other languages.

R. It is used in statistics. It is a highly specialized language that is great for solving statistical problems. But often we need not only to receive data, but also to create a web service so that the user has access to this data. Writing it in R is not easy.

Julia This is quite an interesting language with many design features. Try it if you lack speed or flexibility in Python. However, Julia also has a drawback: its set of tools is still unstable.

Julia –ø—Ä–∏–¥—É–º–∞–ª–∏ –∫–∞–∫ –∞–ª—å—Ç–µ—Ä–Ω–∞—Ç–∏–≤—É Python –∏ MATLAB. –ü–æ—Å–ª–µ–¥–Ω–∏–π –¥–æ —Å–∏—Ö –ø–æ—Ä –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑—É—é—Ç, –Ω–æ —ç—Ç–æ –ø—Ä–æ–ø—Ä–∏–µ—Ç–∞—Ä–Ω–∞—è, ¬´–Ω–µ–∂–∏–≤–∞—è¬ª —Å–∏—Å—Ç–µ–º–∞. –ö–∞–∫ —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –≤—ã –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç–µ –∑–∞ —Ä–∞–º–∫–∏ –ø—Ä–∏–≤—ã—á–Ω—ã—Ö –∑–∞–¥–∞—á, —Ç–æ —Å—Ä–∞–∑—É –æ—â—É—â–∞–µ—Ç–µ –µ–≥–æ –æ–≥—Ä–∞–Ω–∏—á–µ–Ω–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—å.

Julia was invented as an alternative to Python and MATLAB. The latter is still used, but it is a proprietary, ‚Äúnon-living‚Äù system. As soon as you go beyond your usual tasks, you immediately feel its limitations.

Swift. They also tried to make Swift a universal language, but it never went beyond iOS. And then Kotlin appeared, which in syntax is very similar to Swift, but at the same time is suitable for solving a wider range of problems and allows you to work with libraries from Java, JavaScript and C.

Java. I used to program in Java - it’s a cool language that is often unfairly criticized. It was created for the enterprise, so there is an overly drawn-out ‚Äúceremony‚Äù: to build a simple application, you need to write a lot of additional code. Yes, this simplifies support and increases the stability of the application, but it greatly complicates the programming process itself.

Kotlin. Now I write a lot in Kotlin. It has the advantages of Java, but relieves the programmer of a good half of the ‚Äúceremonies‚Äù, and therefore, in my opinion, it has great prospects. What are the main problems in scientific IT and how are they trying to solve them?

‚Äî You mentioned that there was a lot of fancy stuff in science. I wonder if this only applies to Fortran and C++ libraries or something else? And what are the main problems there?

‚ÄúThis is a very big problem that we will have to sort out for a long time.‚Äù The fact is that one day development turned into a separate professional field. 40 years ago, when programming was just in its infancy, physicists were the coolest programmers. They worked on huge machines the size of a closet, and everyone understood everything. But 15‚Äì20 years ago it turned out that software engineering is an independent engineering field.

Scientists fell far behind because they continued to develop software in the same style in which they did it on the antediluvian mainframes. They came up with wonderful algorithms, but did not think at all about code support, testing, CI/CD, and especially about architecture.

For example, data collection systems are completely unable to interact with each other. They were written by different programmers, who sometimes specifically made it so that the systems could not communicate with each other. If two experiments are performed on different systems, then the scientist will have to process their results separately. Moreover, it can take several years to study each system - they are so complex.

Due to the fact that science did not implement modern approaches to software design and did not use new tools, we have accumulated millions of legacy lines. There you can find good and even brilliant algorithms, but it will be almost impossible to understand them. To feel the pain, find a Fortran 77 program and try to understand what’s going on there.

For reference: in Fortran 77, variable name length is limited to eight characters. This means that when all matching variable names run out, the program becomes unreadable. Number-letter identifiers are used, with which the code only becomes more confusing. But most programs in science are still written in Fortran.

Relatively recently, scientists realized that they need to invest in software engineering, pay attention to architecture and master modern tools, and not fence their bicycles. To my surprise, over the past two years, many groups of engineers have emerged that are purposefully promoting the modern approach in science.

Best wishes, Alexander üôå

item.title: Report preparation
item.description:
Internship is an integral part of the educational process, during which a student can learn in more detail about his future profession and demonstrate the acquisition of skills and knowledge. After completing the practical training, a report must be written. In it, the student describes in detail all the actions carried out during the internship at an enterprise or institution. Features of compiling a report on industrial practice and its structure

Features of compiling a report on industrial practice and its structure

The practical training report is presented in the amount of 21-28 sheets of format A, which the student will submit to his supervisor. This is a more difficult option than introductory practice, because here it will not be enough to describe observations and what you saw in the work process. Here the student must conduct an analysis of the organization‚Äôs economic activities and demonstrate materials where these processes will be displayed.

The organization of the internship is the responsibility of the educational institution, but if desired, the student himself can choose the place of internship. Before starting, all students receive specially developed plans for practical training from the educational and scientific department. If a student chooses a place of internship from the list provided by the university, then the possibility of sending the student for practical training and assigning a supervisor from the organization to him is negotiated.

During the internship, the student must comply with the internal regime of the organization, work on an individual task plan, keep a practice diary and prepare a report. Within 5-7 days after the end of the practical training, the teacher must provide a report and a completed diary with the seal of the organization, as well as a reference from the supervisor.

If we talk about the practical training diary, then this is a special document that displays all the work done by the student in the organization. All actions of the trainee are recorded here and thus the teacher can track the activity. The report on practical training must also indicate the objectives of the course, what tasks were assigned to the student and the results of the implementation, as well as the methods that were used to complete the tasks. Preparation of a report on production practice

Preparing a report on industrial practice

According to the structure of the industrial practice report, it contains several parts. Here is a list of required sections:

 - A title page containing the student‚Äôs data, information about the place of internship and educational institution, as well as the year and city of internship.
 - Certificate of practical training, which is filled out on the organization‚Äôs letterhead and contains the seal and signature of the manager.
 - Introductory part of the report. Here the student must describe the place of internship, analyze its activities, assess the market position, show the management system, etc. Be sure to indicate the goals and objectives of the practice in this part.
 - The content or main part of the report has several sections with a total volume of 10-15 pages. Section 1 contains basic information about industrial practice; section 2 indicates the deadlines; section 3 presents the individual task that was assigned to the student for the period of practical training; section 4 contains all the trainee‚Äôs actions by date (the so-called practice diary); Section 5 summarizes the practice and draws relevant conclusions.
 - Feedback from the practice manager from the organization is the main part of the entire report. Here the head of the organization writes about how the trainee managed to prove himself.
 - List of used literature, documentation, regulations and applications.

A description of the activities of an organization or enterprise is a mandatory part of the practice report. The topic to be studied, production problems are also indicated and ways to solve them are formed, what methods will help to conduct the research, and the theory necessary for a full study of production.

Regarding applications, this is also an important part of the internship report, because it is from them that the teacher can clearly evaluate the work done by the student during the internship. This includes documents the trainee worked with, reports, instructions, calculations, technical maps, etc. Can be supplemented with photographs from the internship site.

Separately, it is worth dwelling on the list of literature used, which includes methodological and theoretical instructions, other sources that were used during the period of internship and writing the report. The list is compiled in accordance with the rules and requirements of GOST, which is a single criterion for the preparation of all scientific works. Of course, each educational institution provides its own guidelines, which must also be followed when preparing the report. But they differ only in some details; in general, everything happens in accordance with generally accepted requirements.

The text of the report is written on one side of a sheet of white A4 paper, font ‚Äì Times New Roman, 14 point, line spacing is 1.5. The page number is placed in the middle of the top margin of the sheet; pages of text material should be numbered in Arabic numerals, observing continuous numbering throughout the document. The margins must have indents: 20 mm below and above, 25 mm on the left, 10 mm on the right.

For all students, completing an internship is not only an opportunity to show theoretical knowledge in real life, but also an opportunity to get a job, see how the process works, what responsibilities are assigned. If you need examples to document your practice, you can, of course, find them on the Internet, but it is better to contact the specialists of the Internet portal ‚ÄúI Passed Everything!‚Äù for this. They will help not only with the design, but also with the preparation of the report itself.

Best wishes, Alexander üôå

item.title: Version control. Git
item.description:
Version control is an integral part of software development. It is the process of tracking code changes, coordinating the work of multiple developers, and restoring previous versions of the project when necessary. One of the most popular version control tools is Git. In this blog, we’ll look at the basics of Git and its practical aspects.

What is Git?

Git is a distributed version control system developed by Linus Torvalds. It allows developers to effectively manage changes to the code, create separate development branches, merge them, and track the history of project changes.

Basic principles of Git:

Repository: Git stores all project data in a special repository called a repository. The repository contains the entire history of changes to the project, including files, commits and branches.

Commits: Commits are snapshots of the state of a project at a specific point in time. Each commit contains information about the changes made and the author.

Branching: Branching allows you to create separate development branches in which you can make changes independent of the main branch (usually the master branch). This helps isolate new features or fixes from the main project code.

Merging: Once work on new functionality or bug fixes is completed, changes from a separate branch can be merged into the main branch through a process called merging. This allows you to integrate changes from different branches into the main project code.

Rollback: Git allows you to return to previous states of a project if you need to undo changes or restore previous versions.

Benefits of using Git:

Ease of collaboration on a project for the development team. Git provides mechanisms for collaborative code editing, change tracking, and conflict resolution.

Tracks the history of changes, making it easier to find and fix errors. With Git, developers can easily go back to previous versions of code and examine the change history to find the root cause of problems.

The ability to experiment with new features without damaging the main code. Git allows you to create separate branches to develop new features or experimental changes, which can be integrated into the main project code after successful testing.

Quick restoration of previous versions of the project. If necessary, developers can easily revert to previous versions of a project using Git, ensuring a secure and reliable development process.

Conclusion

Git is a powerful version control tool that greatly simplifies the software development process. Understanding its key principles and basic commands allows developers to effectively version control their projects and make them more reliable and stable. It’s important to note that using Git requires practice and experience, but its basic principles are easy to understand and use in everyday development.

Best wishes, Alexander üôå

item.title: Markdown
item.description:
Markdown is a human-readable markup language that converts transparently to HTML. It can be opened and modified in any text editor. Widely used for writing documentation and README files.

You may encounter Markdown in .md or .markdown files. Let’s look at an example of one of these:

#Doc

Doka is a good encyclopedia for web developers. You can open it in your browser.

Advantages

  • Clear material;
  • Fun explanations;
  • Convenient search.

It contains the basic elements that can be found in almost any README.md:

 first level heading for the title;
 highlighting important parts in the description in bold;
 link with clear text;
 second level heading for subparagraphs;
 bulleted list to list benefits.

Although Markdown is easy to read in its native form, it is often translated into HTML. The conversion result is below.

Syntax

Paragraph

A paragraph is one or more consecutive lines of text separated by one or more blank lines. If a line contains only spaces or tabs, it is still considered empty.

Consecutive lines will be glued into one if you do not add a hard transfer. There are several ways how this can be done:

add two (or more) spaces at the end of the line 
<space><space>;
    add a backslash at the end of the line \;
    add an HTML line break tag <br>.

Hello, world!

tag brrr!

Markdown offers two heading styles: hash marks and underscores. You can use up to six levels of headings, but underlines only allow you to create the first two. ü§ì

In English-language sources, the terms Atx-style (for hash marks) and Setext-style (for underlines) are used to denote heading writing styles. Grilles (Atx-style)

In order to highlight the title, you need to put from 1 to 6 hash marks and a space at the very beginning of the line. The title level depends only on the number of hash marks.

item.title: Writing technical content in Markdown
item.description:
Hugo Blox Builder is designed to give technical content creators a seamless experience. You can focus on the content and Wowchemy handles the rest.

Highlight your code snippets, take notes on math classes, and draw diagrams from textual representation.

On this page, you’ll find some examples of the types of technical content that can be rendered with Wowchemy.

Examples

Code

Wowchemy supports a Markdown extension for highlighting code syntax. You can customize the styles under the syntax_highlighter option in your config/_default/params.yaml file.

```python
import pandas as pd
data = pd.read_csv("data.csv")
data.head()
```

renders as

import pandas as pd
data = pd.read_csv("data.csv")
data.head()

Mindmaps

Wowchemy supports a Markdown extension for mindmaps.

Simply insert a Markdown markmap code block and optionally set the height of the mindmap as shown in the example below.

A simple mindmap defined as a Markdown list:


```markmap {height="200px"}
- Hugo Modules
  - wowchemy
  - blox-plugins-netlify
  - blox-plugins-netlify-cms
  - blox-plugins-reveal
```

renders as

- Hugo Modules
  - wowchemy
  - blox-plugins-netlify
  - blox-plugins-netlify-cms
  - blox-plugins-reveal

A more advanced mindmap with formatting, code blocks, and math:


```markmap
- Mindmaps
  - Links
    - [Wowchemy Docs](https://docs.hugoblox.com/)
    - [Discord Community](https://discord.gg/z8wNYzb)
    - [GitHub](https://github.com/HugoBlox/hugo-blox-builder)
  - Features
    - Markdown formatting
    - **inline** ~~text~~ *styles*
    - multiline
      text
    - `inline code`
    -
      ```js
      console.log('hello');
      console.log('code block');
      ```
    - Math: $x = {-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac} \over 2a}$
```

renders as

- Mindmaps
  - Links
    - [Wowchemy Docs](https://docs.hugoblox.com/)
    - [Discord Community](https://discord.gg/z8wNYzb)
    - [GitHub](https://github.com/HugoBlox/hugo-blox-builder)
  - Features
    - Markdown formatting
    - **inline** ~~text~~ *styles*
    - multiline
      text
    - `inline code`
    -
      ```js
      console.log('hello');
      console.log('code block');
      ```
    - Math: $x = {-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac} \over 2a}$

Charts

Wowchemy supports the popular Plotly format for interactive charts.

Save your Plotly JSON in your page folder, for example line-chart.json, and then add the {{< chart data="line-chart" >}} shortcode where you would like the chart to appear.

Demo:

You might also find the Plotly JSON Editor useful.

Math

Wowchemy supports a Markdown extension for $\LaTeX$ math. You can enable this feature by toggling the math option in your config/_default/params.yaml file.

To render inline or block math, wrap your LaTeX math with {{< math >}}$...${{< /math >}} or {{< math >}}$$...$${{< /math >}}, respectively. (We wrap the LaTeX math in the Wowchemy math shortcode to prevent Hugo rendering our math as Markdown. The math shortcode is new in v5.5-dev.)

Example math block:

{{< math >}}
$$
\gamma_{n} = \frac{ \left | \left (\mathbf x_{n} - \mathbf x_{n-1} \right )^T \left [\nabla F (\mathbf x_{n}) - \nabla F (\mathbf x_{n-1}) \right ] \right |}{\left \|\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n}) - \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n-1}) \right \|^2}
$$
{{< /math >}}

renders as

$$\gamma_{n} = \frac{ \left | \left (\mathbf x_{n} - \mathbf x_{n-1} \right )^T \left [\nabla F (\mathbf x_{n}) - \nabla F (\mathbf x_{n-1}) \right ] \right |}{\left \|\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n}) - \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n-1}) \right \|^2}$$

Example inline math {{< math >}}$\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n})${{< /math >}} renders as $\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n})$.

Example multi-line math using the math linebreak (\\):

{{< math >}}
$$f(k;p_{0}^{*}) = \begin{cases}p_{0}^{*} & \text{if }k=1, \\
1-p_{0}^{*} & \text{if }k=0.\end{cases}$$
{{< /math >}}

renders as

$$ f(k;p_{0}^{*}) = \begin{cases}p_{0}^{*} & \text{if }k=1, \\ 1-p_{0}^{*} & \text{if }k=0.\end{cases} $$

Diagrams

Wowchemy supports a Markdown extension for diagrams. You can enable this feature by toggling the diagram option in your config/_default/params.toml file or by adding diagram: true to your page front matter.

An example flowchart:

```mermaid
graph TD
A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round)
B --> C{Decision}
C -->|One| D[Result 1]
C -->|Two| E[Result 2]
```

renders as

graph TD A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round) B --> C{Decision} C -->|One| D[Result 1] C -->|Two| E[Result 2]

An example sequence diagram:

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you?
loop Healthcheck
    John->>John: Fight against hypochondria
end
Note right of John: Rational thoughts!
John-->>Alice: Great!
John->>Bob: How about you?
Bob-->>John: Jolly good!
```

renders as

sequenceDiagram Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you? loop Healthcheck John->>John: Fight against hypochondria end Note right of John: Rational thoughts! John-->>Alice: Great! John->>Bob: How about you? Bob-->>John: Jolly good!

An example Gantt diagram:

```mermaid
gantt
section Section
Completed :done,    des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08
Active        :active,  des2, 2014-01-07, 3d
Parallel 1   :         des3, after des1, 1d
Parallel 2   :         des4, after des1, 1d
Parallel 3   :         des5, after des3, 1d
Parallel 4   :         des6, after des4, 1d
```

renders as

gantt section Section Completed :done, des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08 Active :active, des2, 2014-01-07, 3d Parallel 1 : des3, after des1, 1d Parallel 2 : des4, after des1, 1d Parallel 3 : des5, after des3, 1d Parallel 4 : des6, after des4, 1d

An example class diagram:

```mermaid
classDiagram
Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool
Class03 *-- Class04
Class05 o-- Class06
Class07 .. Class08
Class09 --> C2 : Where am i?
Class09 --* C3
Class09 --|> Class07
Class07 : equals()
Class07 : Object[] elementData
Class01 : size()
Class01 : int chimp
Class01 : int gorilla
Class08 <--> C2: Cool label
```

renders as

classDiagram Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool Class03 *-- Class04 Class05 o-- Class06 Class07 .. Class08 Class09 --> C2 : Where am i? Class09 --* C3 Class09 --|> Class07 Class07 : equals() Class07 : Object[] elementData Class01 : size() Class01 : int chimp Class01 : int gorilla Class08 <--> C2: Cool label

An example state diagram:

```mermaid
stateDiagram
[*] --> Still
Still --> [*]
Still --> Moving
Moving --> Still
Moving --> Crash
Crash --> [*]
```

renders as

stateDiagram [*] --> Still Still --> [*] Still --> Moving Moving --> Still Moving --> Crash Crash --> [*]

Todo lists

You can even write your todo lists in Markdown too:

- [x] Write math example
  - [x] Write diagram example
- [ ] Do something else

renders as

  • Write math example
    • Write diagram example
  • Do something else

Tables

Save your spreadsheet as a CSV file in your page’s folder and then render it by adding the Table shortcode to your page:

{{< table path="results.csv" header="true" caption="Table 1: My results" >}}

renders as

customer_id score
1 0
2 0.5
3 1
Table 1: My results

Callouts

Academic supports a shortcode for callouts, also referred to as asides, hints, or alerts. By wrapping a paragraph in {{% callout note %}} ... {{% /callout %}}, it will render as an aside.

{{% callout note %}}
A Markdown aside is useful for displaying notices, hints, or definitions to your readers.
{{% /callout %}}

renders as

A Markdown aside is useful for displaying notices, hints, or definitions to your readers.

Spoilers

Add a spoiler to a page to reveal text, such as an answer to a question, after a button is clicked.

{{< spoiler text="Click to view the spoiler" >}}
You found me!
{{< /spoiler >}}

renders as

Click to view the spoiler

You found me!

Icons

Academic enables you to use a wide range of icons from Font Awesome and Academicons in addition to emojis.

Here are some examples using the icon shortcode to render icons:

{{< icon name="terminal" pack="fas" >}} Terminal  
{{< icon name="python" pack="fab" >}} Python  
{{< icon name="r-project" pack="fab" >}} R

renders as

Terminal
Python
R

item.title: Software architecture
item.description:
What is software architecture for?

Software architecture is the foundation of IT product development. Developers write code to create a program. Strings are combined into functions, functions are combined into classes, classes are combined into modules. The result is a finished program.

To reduce the time required to create a complex product, developers at the beginning of work create a general plan for the future software with the main blocks and ways to connect them. Then they detail it, working out the requirements and characteristics. This is how information is obtained to build software components.

First, due to manageability, the architect uses individual components and modules responsible for individual functions to organize software development and support.

Also, the clear architecture of the software product makes it easy to support. Even if developers are not familiar with the details of the system, they will be able to quickly and easily navigate the code, making the team’s work easier.

With the help of software architecture, you can easily modify, expand and scale the project. Quickly add new elements, increase functionality and productivity, and use resources efficiently.

Software architecture, including monolithic architecture, allows for reuse. Components are used multiple times in different parts of the system. The main benefit is to reduce the number of errors and reduce development time. It also includes safety measures to ensure protection.

Basic principles of software architecture

Principles that are taken into account during design.

  • Flexibility. Build not for years, but with the possibility of making changes. Consider how the program may change to meet modern needs, and add flexibility to easily support changes.
  • Openness/closedness. Software entities are closed for modification and open for expansion.
  • Risk reduction and analysis model. It is important to use tools such as UML to capture requirements and design decisions. You should not formalize the model in such a way that it is impossible to easily adapt and repeat the design.
  • Stability - organizing dependencies from more stable components to less stable ones.
  • Uniqueness - avoiding code duplication.
  • Minimal knowledge. Each module knows only about its neighbors to reduce interdependence and increase isolation.
  • Sharing of responsibilities. 1 element - 1 reason for change (for a clear division of responsibilities).

By following these architectural principles, you can design a system that is extensible, flexible, and maintainable.

Types of architectural styles

Architectural styles are high-level strategies. They represent an abstract structure for systems.

8 main styles:

  • Multi-layered.
  • Component-oriented.
  • Service-oriented.
  • Distributed system.
  • Subject-oriented.
  • “Translator”.
  • Parallelism.
  • Data-driven.

Multilayer is the most common. A typical example is a layered style with 3 layers: presentation layer, business logic and data storage. Pros: easy to understand, test and support. The downside is the appearance of performance overhead.

Component-oriented separates functionality into layers within a single system, organized as reusable and loosely coupled components. Advantages: Flexibility, Maintainability, Reusability. Disadvantage: the components are difficult to manage.

Service-oriented for developing software as a set of interacting services over a network. Pros: Loose coupling, flexibility, and reusability. Disadvantages: complexity, network dependence.

Distributed system. Components on networked computers pass messages to communicate and coordinate actions to achieve a goal. Advantages: general access, resistance to errors and failures, scalability. Disadvantages: complexity, network dependence.

Domain-oriented - creation of software abstractions (domain models). It is characterized by limited connections, integrity and interconnection. Disadvantage: Requires deep understanding and experience.

The ‚Äútranslator‚Äù determines how sentences are evaluated. For each symbol, a terminal or non-terminal style is created. It is highly flexible and easy to debug. Disadvantage: Requires more resources.

In the parallelism style, multiple independent tasks are executed at the same time. Parallelism improves performance, which is especially important for multiprocessor systems. The downside is the complex mutual blocking.

Data-centric architecture. The style focuses on organizing and transforming data. Suitable for large volumes of data and solving complex problems. Ensures correct data sequencing, integrity and reliability. Disadvantages include possible scalability issues.

Architectural Patterns

These are subject-specific and specific elements for a particular module or problem. A structured solution that describes the organization of components and interactions. Patterns are similar to software design patterns, but more abstract.

Each architectural style has its own patterns. Multilayer has a multi-layer pattern and ‚ÄúClean Architecture‚Äù. The first divides the system into a certain number of layers, each with its own area of responsibility. The ‚ÄúClean Architecture‚Äù pattern emphasizes the separation of functionality in the system, organizing software into concentric layers, in the central one - the subject area, in a circle - specific layers for the application, the internal ones influence the external ones. So the changes have almost no effect on the business logic.

There are 3 patterns in the component-oriented style. Object-oriented pattern is a paradigm with objects containing data in the form of fields (attributes) and code in the form of procedures (methods). Facilitates the design of complex systems, their implementation and support. “Microkernel” to separate the microkernel from the extended client-specific functionality. This way you can easily and quickly expand the system without changing the main code. Plugin pattern - adds new functionality using modules or plugins, integrating them through a standard interface to expand and customize the application.

Service-oriented style patterns:

  • SOA. A software project is a set of individual services that are used in systems.
  • Broker. Coordinates the communication of system components through an intermediary.
  • Microservice pattern for architecture. An application project looks like a collection of small services. Each service communicates through lightweight mechanisms and operates in its own process.
  • Serverless pattern. Applications are created and run without servers in cloud environments.

The distributed system style has 2 patterns:

  • Data space. Evenly distributes resources and services across servers, which avoids a single point of failure.
  • Peer-to-peer network. Here, each participant acts as a client. Nodes and service exchange data without a central server.

By understanding styles and patterns, a specialist will be able to design reliable, scalable and maintainable systems.

Best wishes, Alexander üôå
